reviewText: Beware of the Spoilers.Kevin Willmott's "CSA: The Confederate States of America" is an excellent film. Whether you love the Confederacy or hate it, this film, as it says, provides a fascinating and provocative look into a very different America that might have been. It is presented as a British documentary in the alternate world the movie envisions, and it is indicated early on that censorship in the CSA came close to preventing the documentary from ever being seen. In this alternate world, history diverges from how we know it just before Gettysburg, when Judah P. Benjamin succeeds in gaining the CSA military aid from Britain and France, causing Gettysburg to be a crushing defeat for the United States. The Confederacy soon invades in return, storming Washington, DC and taking the White House. President Lincoln has fled, and the primary objective of the Confederacy is now to find and capture him. Lincoln is being smuggled across the border to Canada by another enemy of the Confederate States, Harriet Tubman, when Confederate troops hunt him down. Tubman is soon hung, and though many voices are clamoring for the execution of former President Lincoln, President Jefferson Davis decides not to do so, believing that sparing him will help to mend the rift between North and South. The CSA soon annexes the USA, and goes on to take over Central and South America, creating the tropical empire that some Confederate leaders one day hoped to create. Lincoln dies lonely and bitter, exiled to Canada, and his Emancipation Proclamation is insignificant and forgotten, much as he is, in the history books. Canada becomes a defiant holdout against Confederate expansionism, swayed against deporting fleeing slaves by a powerful speech made to Canadian Parliament by Frederick Douglass. This decision begins a long, long relationship of mutual dislike between the CSA and Canada, eventually resulting in an alternate Cold War between the two nations that continues to the present day. The Confederacy does not make any separation between church and state, and ensures its status as a Christian nation by outlawing all other religions. Jews, in a totally inadequate gesture of thanks for the service of Judah P. Benjamin, are allowed to remain on reservations.The Great Depression is ended by a slavery-related act passed by the CS President, exporting large numbers of slaves overseas. When Adolf Hitler rises to power in Germany, the two nations become very friendly, with Confederate politicians attending Nazi rallies, and Hitler making a personal visit to the Confederate States. No official alliance is ever established, but the CSA promises it will make no move against Germany in any wars it has with its neighbors. World War II still ends with a German defeat- I consider that rather unrealistic, but not impossible, much as I see this film overall- but with much heavier Soviet losses. The Pacific, however, is far more different. The CSA preemptively assaults numerous Imperial Japanese bases and colonies on 12-7-1941, battling their way across the Pacific and ending the war through use of the atomic bomb. A black infantry unit is commissioned, and the soldiers who fight in it act as a massive slap in the face to prevailing Confederate views- that blacks are genetically inferior to whites and incapable of matching them in talent and intelligence- distinguish themselves under fire, going on the most dangerous missions their white officers can find and taking high losses in the process. The black soldiers were promised freedom if they served honorably, but this turns out to be a lie- the men are sent back to their owners in chains. The 1950's-1970's are troubled years, with slave rebellions, anti-slavery terrorist attacks, and an expansionist war in Vietnam. When John F. Kennedy is elected President, the first Northerner to obtain the Presidency since Lincoln, polls show that well under half of the CSA's populace favors slavery, the lowest figures in history. Women demand to be more than the property of men. Both emancipation for slaves and voting rights for women seem imminent, until Kennedy is assassinated. The CSA instead continues on its white supremacist track, keeping slaves and denying equal rights to women until the present date. Canada becomes the America we know in many ways, being vastly more popular worldwide and possessing the culture Confederate censorship makes impossible. Confederate culture never progresses beyond government-inspired propaganda.I believe this scenario to be unlikely, but not impossible. The Confederacy had relatively little interest in conquering the USA, which was on the other hand obsessed with conquering its Southern neighbor. International pressure and rising numbers of slave rebellions would have likely forced the CSA to abandon slavery long before the present date. Still, given that every alteration of history, any change to any battle, law, or war can create an entirely different world, it is quite possible that this exact scenario could have occurred. I do not believe that the Confederacy's dedication to holding slaves was so extreme. However, the film is superbly made, and whether you agree with it or not, a fascinating film that I highly recommend. As a final note, I have no idea why some have called this a satire. None.
summary: Flawed and not the best alternate history work made, but I love it anyway.

reviewText: "CSA: Confederate States of America" is a mockumentary. Knowing this should be sufficient to clue us in on what to expect and to not expect.First, it's alternate history. Alternate history is extremely hard (indeed, well nigh impossible) to predict with accuracy. What CSA portrays is just one of many, many scenarios that could have played out had the South won the Civil War. (For example, given the states' rights bent of the Confederacy and the precedent that secession would have set, one plausible alternative history would include many squabbling little countries instead of a unified CSA.) I seriously doubt that it was the intent of the producers of this film to portray what they thought was the only or even the most plausible alternate outcome.Second, its intent is not to portray the Confederacy with perfect accuracy. While a more sympathetic portrayal would have been nice (including the fact that there were many in the South, including Lee and Davis, who believed slavery was a dying institution), it would have made for a rather boring movie.Third, while it may appear to some to be biased against the South and certainly does not account for the very real possibility that moral progress may have taken place even if the South had won the war, its bias is not so blatant as to detract from what this movie is--a satirical and often funny thought experiment.If the viewer is willing to take CSA as less a piece of serious social commentary than as a humorous and somewhat lighthearted look into an alternate universe that never materialized, it will provide an hour and a half of enjoyable entertainment.
summary: Take it for what it's supposed to be

reviewText: The premise of "CSA: The Confederate States of America" is terrific!  Creative.  Imaginative.  Potentially, a lot of fun.  If in a parallel universe or dimension the Confederates won the Civil War, how would the 19th and 20th centuries have changed? What would life be like today?  Those are the very questions that director Kevin Willmott and producer Spike Lee attempt to answer in an ingeniously conceived, but sadly, an intellectually dishonest film.The context of "CSA" is a documentary film produced by the "British Broadcasting Service" just after the turn of the 21st century in a world in which the Confederates had won "War of Northern Aggression" in 1864.  The viewer watches the 89-minute film, interrupted only by the "commercials" which market to its parallel world audience such products as Confederate Insurance, S!mb$ Motor Oil, and D!rk#@ Toothpaste, among several others.  Interestingly, some of the mock advertisements represented products that did actually exist at one time. The film also uses every opportunity to use icons and terms to contrast the real world with the filmmakers' own construct of an alternate universe.  For example, the NAACP stands for the National Association for the Advancement of Chattel People.  There is not mention of the Berlin Wall, but rather there is a "Cotton Wall" erected between the CSA and Canada, where the "John Brown Underground" uses terrorist tactics in an attempted to bring about an end to slavery. Although not all of the acting is particularly credible, the film does provide viewers who live in this dimension a palpable creepiness as scenes of a past and contemporary segregated America using real, historical film footage and photographs are flashed on the television screen.As inventive and clever the film's delivery is, however, the unlikelihood of the events that unfolded on screen are difficult to conceive, not only for a student of American history, but also for the average viewer.  The Confederacy won the war, suggest the film's writers, because CSA Secretary of State Judah Benjamin was able to secure the support of England and France against the Union.  (Had England and France joined the war, it is possible and likely that the Confederacy would have been victorious.)  Just as the "real" Abraham Lincoln had in fact waited for a decisive victory for the Union to announce the Emancipation Proclamation, the CSA wanted to wait for a Confederate victory in battle before securing the support of the two European superpowers of the 19th century.  That decisive victory did not come at the right time for the Jefferson Davis government.However, in the alternate universe after Grant surrendered to Lee, Abraham Lincoln was forced to enlist Harriett Tubman and her Underground Railroad to assist the cowardly Lincoln away from Washington D.C. and to safety.  The two are captured, Lincoln, disguised in blackface, and Tubman is eventually hanged while Lincoln looks through his small, barred cell window.  Willmott continues to suggest a bigoted and angry South as Confederate soldiers continue to march northward to burn both New York City and Boston to the ground.  These acts of wanton destruction, then, required "Reconstruction" in the North overseen by the Confederate States' government, now secure in Washington D.C.  The Reconstruction included, in part, the choice of Northerners to either pay a high Reconstruction tax or to get-with-the-program by purchasing a slave.  In contrast, the real-life Lincoln simply allowed Jefferson Davis and to leave the Confederate capital after the fighting had ceased and permitted, for the most part, Confederate soldiers to peacefully return home to their farms and businesses.The film continues to move further away from a likely historical scenario toward barefaced liberal, and even race-baiting propaganda as the alternate reality Confederate States of America enslave Chinese, American Indians, and Japanese during expansion to the American West and during the Industrial Revolution.  In addition, the C.S.A. annexes all of South America and supports and reveres Adolph Hitler for his ideas and ideals relating to a pure Arian race in Europe.  Willmott even discretely makes the point that Abraham Lincoln was not actually an abolitionist himself to denigrate the extraordinary accomplishments and leadership of the Kentuckian during the most difficult time in our nation's history.  While it is arguable and would certainly not have correlated with the film makers' message, the more likely and more intellectually sincere outcome of a Confederate victory would have been a separate Confederate States of America in the South along with a United States of America in the North.  And, as like every civilized country in the world has done, the CSA would likely have successfully found a solution to end slavery, as well.In short, what could have been a historically interesting, fun, and groundbreaking film that still could possibly have made some important points about people, politics, and opinions in America, devolved into something else.  The suggestion that Americans from southern states were (and may continue to be) ignorant racists is offensive.  The subtle implication that widespread stereotyping lies just below the surface propagates distrust between Americans is as disturbing as it is counterproductive.  Fortunately, and in spite of  "CSA: The Confederate States of America" bordering on racism, the United States of America is, in fact, a place where citizens are free to express their opinion through a right of free speech.
summary: Ingeniously conceived, but sadly, an intellectually dishonest film

reviewText: The "what if" game popular among intellectual hopefuls comes to the screen in this reflection on how the USA  -- ahem, the CSA! - would have developed had the South won the War between the States. Presented as a British documentary detailing the history of America, the film puts archival film to new uses and creates new, period-accurate material to tell its story. Starting with a Southern win at Gettysburg - with British and French assistance - the Confederacy goes from strength to strength until it occupies Washington, DC and puts Jeff Davis in the White House. In a D.W. Griffith-esque silent film - a parody of "The Birth of a Nation" -- the new government hunts down "Dishonest Abe" Lincoln, who had been fleeing to Canada in the company of Harriet Tubman. The CSA legalizes slavery in all states. It sits out the war with equally racist Nazi Germany, and finds itself at odds with slavery-abolishing Canada, where much of the black American intelligentsia has fled.Interestingly, much of American history went on unchanged. Wilbur and Orville still flew at Kitty Hawk and Americans still walked on the moon (albeit after hoisting the Stars and Bars, rather than the Stars and Stripes). But as many of the film's mock commercials indicate, life for blacks barely changed. Indeed the film opens with a commercial for life insurance to protect a white man's family and (panning to a black man trimming the hedges) his property."The Confederates States of America" is a cleverly made, often funny, and inspired piece of imagination. It suggests that a paranoid, male-dominated, slave-oppressing and culturally-impoverished America -- think of a north-of-the-equator version of apartheid South Africa -- would have been the result of a win by the South. Given the century of struggle that it took blacks to win full rights even WITH a Northern victory, and the important tie between slave freedom and women's suffrage, these conclusions are not far-fetched. The film's small touches were perfect and eay to miss. A speaker is labeled the author of "The Gray and the Blue," neatly placing the victor's colors foremost. The secession of Southern states was never mentioned -- rather, Jeff Davis established a "provisional government" in response to Lincoln's electoral victory. Paintings of Lee's surrender to Grant at Appomattox worked as well when described as depicting Grant's surrender to Lee. Tye real-life Watts riots were recast as a slave rebellion. A real JFK Cold War speech about slavery and freedom under Communism sounded in "CSA" like a call to emancipate America's still-enslaved blacks.I gently object to the film being labeled a mockumentary. "This is Spinal Tap!" and "A Mighty Wind" made fun of their subjects, even while celebrating them. But the subject of "CSA"  is no laughing matter. It's not clear that America could have continued as a slave-holding nation had the South won the war. But the film did make me think again about those who, even today, see the Civil War as a simple misunderstanding between (white) gentlemen about states rights. The welfare and self-worth of millions of human beings depended on the outcome of the war. Whether "CSA" is accurate in its portrayal of a Southern victory is besides the point; the film's value is in helping us reconsider the war's meaning, and how it changed America -- for good and for ill."CSA" is not about refighting the Civil War or of demonizing the South. It is a briliant exercise in imagination that should help us reflect on the stakes over which that war was fought and over the continued fight to wring meaning from its horrendous bloodshed.

In all such territory, the institution of negro slavery as it now exists in the Confederate States, shall be recognized and protected by Congress, and by the territorial government: and the inhabitants of the several Confederate States and Territories, shall have the right to take to such territory any slaves lawfully held by them in any of the states or territories of the Confederate states.This proves that anyone who claims that the Civil War was not, at its core, about slavery, is a liar and a fraud. The entire economy of the South was dependent on slavery. The spark for secession was Lincoln's intention to prohibit both slavery and black settlement in the new western territories, with the inevitable outcome that poor southern whites would have emigrated, leaving the plantation owners alone with no protection from a slave rebellion. The "Bleeding Kansas" controversy demonstrated the deep conflict over whether slavery would be allowed in the new western states.How all of this would have played out given a Confederate victory is pure speculation, and the filmmakers, to underscore their point, assume the most extreme outcome, where slavery ultimately spreads worldwide. Its presentation in the form of a documentary intended to aquaint foreign viewers with an essential episode in American history allows the film to give clear, simple explanations that American (Confederate?) viewers presumably would have been well aware of.I was initially put off by the apparent outrageousness of the "commercials," supposedly for products only available in the alternate reality of the film's world, until the one for "Coon Chicken," which I was already familiar with, the logo having been used by a character on the HBO series "Six Feet Under" for an art project. People complain about political correctness, but there's something to be said for not deliberately going out of your way to insult an entire race. The real lesson of "CSA" is not simply that it could have been our fate, but that only for a few fortuitous circumstances, it almost was.

reviewText: This film sets out to make the viewer realise how much evil was caused by slavery, presenting itself as a documentary being made in an "alternative history" world in which the South won the American civil war and slavery continues to this day.The mechanics of how history came to follow an alternative track are deliberately downplayed: this film is not really about how any specific change in the timeline could have produced particular consequences. The fact that in a few instances the alternate history timeline is very implausible does not matter to this film, where it might have ruined a different type of film in which the history was the story.For instance, it is one thing to suggest that the Confederate States of America might have won independence if they could get British and French support. It is an entirely different matter to suggest that the rebels could have actually conquered and annexed the North. If the main message of the film had been that this could have happened it would have completely destroyed the credibility of the story. However, as the main purpose of the story is to make the evil of slavery real to us by showing how it would have worked in a modern context, the makers of the film can plausibly argue that they more effectively make that point by showing slavery in action throughout the area which in our world is the United States of America and in the film is the Confederate States of America.The opening sequence starts with a disclaimer that this is a "foreign" documentary made by the "British Broadcasting Service" (which doesn't exist) - this is part of the scene setting. The film is interspersed with adverts for various services and products set in a world in which slavery is normal and both racism and sexism are much more overt and direct than we are used to seeing. At the very end of the film there is an explanation of how much of this advertising is lifted from real adverts for real products, which will shock many people.Part of the film is presented as a history programme about the "Confederate States" and part as an expose of the supposed current social and political situation.The film loves taking real events and reversing them: for example the real painting of the surrender at the end of the civil war is described as Grant's surrender to Lee, we see film of the TV debate in the US presidential election of 1960, and it is described as being between Democrat candidate Richard Nixon and Republican candidate John F Kennedy.This year, 2007, sees the 200th anniversary of the vote by the British parliament to abolish the slave trade. Many organisations including the Anglican (Episcopal) church and my local council in Copeland (which includes Whitehaven) are marking this by organising ceremonies to apologise for their role in slavery.It's easy to get cynical about this, especially while we have a Prime Minister who is constantly apologising for things which Britain did centuries ago but who has never once apologised for any of the things for which he is actually responsible. However, if I had been in any doubt that we should express our regrets and apology for the fact that our ancestors were once involved in the slave trade - and on the positive side, that anyone with ancestors who helped to stop the slave trade and bring emancipation can be proud of the fact - this film would have dispelled it.

reviewText: You really are on the wrong track if you start carping on the historical improbabilities of this film.  Many in the North and South had already recognized that slavery was becoming more and more financially untenable and many prominent Southerners were opposed to slavery (such as Robert E. Lee) and there is simply no possible way that the South could have won the Civil War (Lee hoped that the North would become weary of fighting and just leave the South alone - no one in the South thought that they could actually defeat the North).  But none of this matters.  This is a comic look at American History with the aim of mining an alternative American history for any potential humor.  In this regard the documentary is a huge success.  The film really doesn't make many deep political points.  It just tries to generate laughs by a parody of American History.The film is structured as a British documentary that is being shown in America, thus allowing the inclusion of Confederate States of America commercials.  There are some delightful twists, such as Canada developing as an enemy as dangerous as the Soviet Union, due to the nation's views on slavery.  The commercials are funny and actually quite on target if you are familiar with racially edged commercials from the late 19th century.  I also enjoyed the twists on world history, with the CSA taking a different relationship with countries like Nazi Germany (advocating that Germany enslave the Jews rather than kill them) and the conceit that writers like Richard Wright and James Baldwin would be Canadian writers.  I also loved twists like Canada dominating the C.S.A. in sports due to blacks participating there.I can understand people who - for whatever reason - find this film offensive.  But I think as many or more will find it bitingly funny.

reviewText: C.S.A. is a movie that examines what life might have been like if the Confederacy would have won the American Civil War.  The film begins with a commercial about insurance.  It is one of many faux television advertisements scattered throughout the picture.  After the insurance commercial, there is a warning that the following film might offend some people.  Then the actual "broadcast" presentation of C.S.A. begins.  In the world of the film, the South wins Gettysburg and because of that Judah P. Benjamin successfully convinces not only England, but also France that the real issue of the war isn't slavery, but states' rights and they join the Rebel grey on the battlefield.  The Union had more than enough troops to outfight the Confederacy alone, but not enough to fight the armies of two other countries.  Lee marches on Washington, D.C. and other Confederate generals pillage and burn Boston and New York.  Meanwhile, President Lincoln is forced to flee, but is caught with Harriet Tubman just south of the Canadian border disguised in blackface.  Tubman is hanged and Lincoln is imprisoned for two years at Fortress Monroe.  Upon his release Lincoln moves to Canada and lives out his life there.  Emboldened by their victory the Confederacy begins a different form of Reconstruction, offering to rebuild the destroyed Northern cities with "free" slave labor.  There are rebellions here and there, but they are quickly put down and those who dissent are executed.  A huge number of abolitionists, scholars, and religious leaders leave the Confederacy for Canada.  Western expansion is continued and the Native Indians are either exterminated or forced to flee to Canada, too.  There are no Indian reservations in this alternative timeline. Chinese workers in the west are made slaves, too.  Emboldened by their successes, the Confederacy sets it sights on a world empire and begins a war into Central and then South America.  The expansion succeeds, though at a great cost, and by the early part of the 20th Century all of South America is a part of the Confederate States of America.  The Confederacy stays out of the European field of WWII, but fights alone against Japan.  Seeking to slay the dragon before it can strike, the C.S.A. attacks Japan.  The war is long and bloody, but the development of the atomic bomb brings the surrender of the Japanese empire.  The 1950s bring a time of peace and prosperity to the nation-empire, but the 1960s bring distress.  John F. Kennedy defeats Richard Nixon for the Presidency and his election brings the hope for woman's suffrage and the emancipation of the slaves.  However, all such hopes are dashed when Kennedy is assassinated.  The threat of "terrorists" from Canada and the bleeding of Canadian culture into the fabric of Confederate society forces the Confederate to build a huge concrete wall across the Canadian/C.S.A. border that is nicknamed the Cotton Curtain.There are some that will have a problem with the fake history presented in C.S.A.  For instance, the South didn't seem to have any plans to annex the Northern states.  They just wanted to win the war and be left alone.  Yet, if the Confederacy had won a major battle like Gettysburg and been joined by the British and French their plans could have changed.  The Union would never be okay with the South seceding.  Another war further in the future would probably have been inevitable.The probabilities and what-ifs of history aside, C.S.A. is an ambitious film, and though it suffers from a miniscule budget there are moments when the movie really shines.  For instance, many of the television commercials shown throughout the "broadcast presentation" are brilliant in their execution, such as the commercial for a COPS parody called RUNAWAY and an animated commercial featuring the Gold Dust Twins.  Some of these ads remind me of skits from CHAPELLE'S SHOW.  These ads take on more significance when one discovers at the end of the movie that most of them are about products that actual existed or are still in existence.There are also a couple of movie recreations that are done particularly well.  A silent film by D.W. Griffith about the capture of Abraham Lincoln is one example.  This film within a film captures the essence of many silent films of the era, extended gestures, overemphasized facial features, and all.  Another example is the movie I MARRIED AN ABOLITIONIST that captures the feel of 1950s sci-fi movies, such as INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS.  By the same token there are other movie recreations that don't come off so well and look more like a "movie" created by a person with their personal video camera.There are a couple of problems I have with the movie.  The first is the historical portrayal of Abraham Lincoln.  A video of Lincoln near the end of his life in 1905 is shown and it has Lincoln saying that his biggest regret is that he never took slavery seriously and that he just used slaves for political purposes.  Lincoln never did do that.  It was a well known fact that Lincoln was an abolitionist.  It was because of his election to the Presidency that the Southern states seceded.  Abolition had been talked of since the signing of the U.S. Constitution and the Southern states knew that with Lincoln as President slavery would soon come to an end.  The remarks the Lincoln of C.S.A. makes are ones completely out of character even for a Lincoln living in a world where the Confederacy won and slavery was still legal.The second issue I had with C.S.A. is the acting, particularly that done by the man portraying John Ambrose Fauntroy V.  I realize that this is a very low budget feature.  I also realize there are times when the acting is supposed to be cheesy.  However, Fauntroy's character is a major player in the movie, but he comes off being as more of a cartoon than a real life politician.C.S.A. is an interesting, entertaining, and satirical film.  The ambition of the project superceded the movie's budget, but that doesn't affect the ideas the film raises.The DVD includes several extras including a commentary with director Kevin Willmott and producer Rick Cowan, another commentary with just Kevin Willmott, some deleted and extended scenes, a short making-of featurette, and a few trailers for other movies.
summary: What If the South Never Fell? 3 1/2 Stars

reviewText: This movie contains far too many wasted minutes of poor script, bad acting, awkward/weak premise, lost direction and focus, ungainly pace, lamentable costumes and make-up, and insufferably poor parody and satire. Presenting us with a fake BBC-style documentary (oddly, actually it's a very poorly imitated Ken Burns rip) covering the "history" of a triumphant Confederate States of America to the present day, the filmmakers show nothing more than a superficial grasp of the subject they fail to satirize, and demonstrate a poor understanding of the forces of history--even as a satirical subject. They bend world history grotesquely out of shape so they can work in disconnected vignettes that I'm sure they thought were cute. The endlessly misfiring effort concludes--in the laboring mightily and producing a mouse fashion--with a postlude revealing the "truth" of some of the bits presented, and ending with a pretty silly and anti-climactic condemnation of Uncle Ben and Aunt Jemimah--the twin pillars of racism in America today.I'm not at all critiquing the presumed point of the endeavor, although I was really hard-pressed to find one and what's there does need critiquing, as the film hovers uneasily somewhere in the "controversy-packed" (irony here) realm of "institutional racism is bad" and "slavery was bad" and "white people are awful especially the darn rednecks"--all cheap shots and dead horses that have been flogged in recent years to the consistency of shredded wheat. As satire--the real issue here, since that's what this film purports to be--it's just plain gawd-awful and the fact that the premise is that the film was a BBC-ish documentary is also mind-bendingly ironic. British TV has produced many of the finest political and social satires going (try "Whoops, Apocalypse! for starters)and nearly anything from that source puts this astoundingly inept offering to shame. Decent American TV comedy shows, especially those on Comedy Central have covered any bits and pieces of what's offered in this amateurish assembly with greater force and originality. This is the clumsiest and most directionless social/political "satire" I've ever seen, bar none.Worse, the "mockumentary" is interrupted with badly done fake TV commercials for products that are based on old racist-logo products that once existed. They serve no real satiric purpose--anyone who doesn't know about this sort of marketing in the past, especially if they're hip to racial issues, has been living in a cave, and the relevancy to modern culture, beyond the tiresome Ben/Jemimah dinosaurs is zilch. The filmmakers instead, by wanting to seem clever, threw away an opportunity to focus on other aspects of this alternate C.S.A. history that would have had much greater contemporary relevancy and would have been a heck of a lot funnier. There's a particularly stillborn segment on selling slaves on the Home Shopping Network that showed no mental effort whatsoever (just imagine it, and that's all you get). Anyway, TV commercial parodies gain their force by mixing excellent simulations of the real deal with subversive content--they should look and smell like real TV commercials of today, not like middle-school comedy sketches or commercials of 20 years ago. Paul Verhoeven is the director to study for this, and Saturday Night Live is always great at fake commercials.Overall, this film was largely underdeveloped "concept" and poor follow through. For the sake of some tacky jokes--like Lincoln in black-face escaping to Canada--it substitutes historical complexities with just more stereotyping and simple-mindedness, which is a problem a lot of politically driven people have with their so-called "humor" these days. The fact that it's been lauded by more than a few--even called "daring," which is utterly absurd since when in the last decades has demonizing the South or people not-of-color been daring?--really worries me, as it indicates a near fatal fall from the heights of, say, Dr. Strangelove or The President's Analyst or Watermelon Man to the lowest art and meanest quality.Good satire should make you chuckle, laugh outright, AND make you think. Great satire should make you feel humble and a little ashamed, as few of us aren't hypocrites or jerks of one sort or another, and it should have the ability to lure in the opposition and make them think a bit too. Otherwise, what's the point? You know, fans of this stuff (and the half-baked efforts of people like Michael Moore, who really needs more criticism from people who agree with his general goals) need to get beyond the point where anything--no matter how poorly rendered--that's against war or racism or sexism or whatnot is just dandy. To be brutally honest, people I know who tolerate and enjoy this sort of incompetent drivel usually never made it beyond a 101 level course in Race in America and tend to feel a little too smug about their predictable set of "correct" postures (Bush bad, war bad, racism bad) that are seldom backed with any real thought and are always expressed most eloquently with a bumper sticker. "Racism bad" is a fine and noble position to take but if there's no further understanding of the issues involved then the attitude contributes nothing to dealing with very current and very real issues. This movie adds nothing to anyone's understanding of anything about racism, and simply because it took a vaguely "correct' stance does not exempt it from criticism.The "Dreadful Truth" is that Americans who produce and consume this kind of lifestyle "product"--and don't have any illusions that it's anything but, since, like most Michael Moore product, it's marketed to no one but fellow believers--need to stop reassuring themselves about their "righteousness," and entertaining themselves with smug humor, and instead get down to the hard work of winning over other people... and winning elections. One less sanctimonius documentary on how Bush "stole" the 2000 election or how voters are brainless sheep ("stupidist people on Earth" sez Mr. Moore--and that certainly helped the cause), and one more documentary that maybe sells progressive ideas to average Americans. PLEASE! reviewText: "CSA" takes the format of the broadcast of a faux British documentary about the history of slavery in the CS after the War of Northern Aggression. It's punctuated with commercials that suggest what life would be like in a society that has thoroughly integrated slavery into its basic structure.Contrary to what some reviewers claim, the documentary is a coherent, well-worked-out speculative history of what might have happened if the South had won. Some of it is based on what the South did, or wanted to do (the invasion and subjugation of South America, for example); most of the rest seems plausible, if only in terms of "human nature".Several reviewers correctly pointed out that all the South wanted was the right to continue to spread slavery to states entering the Union, and that it had no /intention/ of conquering the North. This overlooks the fact that the only way it could have had what it wanted was by overthrowing the US government and seizing power. The South /did/ invade the North, and had it seized Washington, it's unlikely it would have simply walked away from the opportunity to take control. Would you?If you're expecting an SNL or MAD TV sketch, you'll be disappointed. Though there are slap-your-knee/laugh-out-loud moments, the subject matter and its basically serious presentation prevent most of it from being amusing.Highly recommended, if you have the stomach for this sort of thing.
